definitions.definition: Placed at the end of a sentence to accentuate the mood or attitude of the speaker.
Placed at the end of a sentence to convey reassurance or express solidarity .
examples: You won’t drown one lah . The water is very shallow.

definitions.definition: Indicates an attempt at expressing sympathy , being sincere , conveying informality or establishing a rapport with the listener.
examples: Just try your best lah , and don’t think too much about it.

definitions.definition: Placed at the end of an assertive statement to express denial or dismissiveness .
examples: — I don’t think you should be cutting corners, at least put in some effort and make it look legit. — They won’t care one lah ... I don’t have all day...

definitions.definition: Used after an assertive statement to reinforce its authoritativeness , or to show that the speaker is confident with what they are saying.
examples: These shoes are too small lah .
No need to count lah . I’m sure the number is right.

definitions.definition: Asserts that something is clear, obvious or straightforward .
examples: Get a whiteboard marker and write over it lah .
They’re not wrong lah ... But they’re only taking themselves into consideration.

definitions.definition: Used to tone down an imperative sentence, so it sounds more like a request or suggestion .
Indicates strong persuasion at the end of an imperative sentence.
examples: Don’t waste your time there lah .

definitions.definition: Indicates a retrospective remark , a reassessment of one’s opinion, or an attempt at finding a middle ground .
examples: — Not many people would think of using a pressure cooker. — I mean, it’s pretty unconventional lah , I have to admit.

definitions.definition: Reinforces a suggestion with the implication that it is the more practical option.
examples: The nearest train station is 15 minutes away. I think we take the bus lah , hor ?

definitions.definition: Indicates confirmation -seeking at the end of an inferential statement.
examples: In other words, you’re the one who started it lah !

definitions.definition: Used to express realisation , or vexation when something is already obvious.
examples: So in the end it wasn’t my fault lah !
Do it yourself lah ! Always need me to help is it ?

definitions.definition: Reinforces the factuality of an assertive statement made to correct an inaccurate, underlying assumption .
examples: Oh wait it’s not today, lah . It’s on Sunday.

definitions.definition: Used to convey a slight sense of dissatisfaction or irritation .
An assertive separator, used to reverse the order of the usual topic–comment structure of a sentence.
definitions.label_groups: chiefly Malaysia , less common in Singapore

main_definition: Placed at the end of a sentence to accentuate the mood or attitude of the speaker.
secondary_definitions: Placed at the end of a sentence to convey reassurance or express solidarity .
Indicates an attempt at expressing sympathy , being sincere , conveying informality or establishing a rapport with the listener.
Placed at the end of an assertive statement to express denial or dismissiveness .
Used after an assertive statement to reinforce its authoritativeness , or to show that the speaker is confident with what they are saying.
Asserts that something is clear, obvious or straightforward .
Used to tone down an imperative sentence, so it sounds more like a request or suggestion .
Indicates strong persuasion at the end of an imperative sentence.
Indicates a retrospective remark , a reassessment of one’s opinion, or an attempt at finding a middle ground .
Reinforces a suggestion with the implication that it is the more practical option.
Indicates confirmation -seeking at the end of an inferential statement.
Used to express realisation , or vexation when something is already obvious.
( less common ) Reinforces the factuality of an assertive statement made to correct an inaccurate, underlying assumption .
( less common ) Used to convey a slight sense of dissatisfaction or irritation .
( chiefly Malaysia , less common in Singapore ) An assertive separator, used to reverse the order of the usual topic–comment structure of a sentence.
